snippet: Security researchers say consumers should make sure they change their passwords after a flaw on some websites is fixed, but figuring that out may not be easy.
abstract: Extent of programming mistake known as Heartbleed, which leaves sensitive personal information of consumers on some websites unprotected, is unclear; some experts advise consumers to change their passwords at any site that holds sensitive data, even if it means needing to change them again when the flaw is fixed; others warn changing passwords before sites are patched could simply lead to re-exposure.
lead_paragraph: Security researchers say consumers should make sure they change their passwords after a flaw on some websites is fixed, but figuring that out may not be easy.

headline.main: Flaw Calls for Altering Passwords, Experts Say
headline.print_headline: Flaw Calls for Altering Passwords, Experts Say
